identificationModule.briefTitle: Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Cerebral Ischemia in Patients With Takayasu Arteritis (TARIC-1)
identificationModule.officialTitle: Safety and Efficacy of Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Cerebral Ischemia in Patients With Takayasu Arteritis: a Prospective Cohort Study

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The aim of this study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of remote ischemic conditioning ( RIC ) in the protection of cerebral ischemia in patients with Takayasu arteritis ( TAK ). The study was designed as a prospective, double-blind, exploratory randomized controlled study. The entire study included a screening period and a treatment observation period ( a total of 24 weeks ). All patients with cerebral ischemia of TAK will be randomly divided into RIC group and sham RIC group at 1:1 ratio. On the basis of receiving the conventional drug therapy, the patients will be treated with RIC or sham RIC treatment twice daily for six month. The clinical data of patients at baseline and each follow-up will be collected, including basic information, disease activity assessment, laboratory indicators, imaging indicators, treatment data, adverse events, etc.The Primary outcome is the mean cerebral blood flow improvement rate ( mCBF-IR ) of TAK patients after 24 weeks-treatment. Secondary endpoints include the incidence of major adverse cerebrovascular events ( MACE ) , the change value of arterial transit time ( ATT ) in pCASL hypoperfusion area compared with baseline, occurrence of RIC-related adverse reactions, the changes of hematological indexes and disease activity score, etc. This study will provide insights into the preliminary proof of principle, safety, and efficacy of RIC in cerebral ischemia in patients with Takayasu arteritis ( TAK ), and this data will provide parameters for future larger scale clinical trials if efficacious.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Clinical symptoms, routine follow-up laboratory tests, other serological indicators (VEGF, NGF, ET-1, ACE), PAF, PDGF, etc.), vascular involvement, cranial MRI, vascular injury score, disease activity and treatment will be collected at baseline. After RIC or sham RIC intervention, clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, disease activity, treatment and RIC-related adverse reactions will be collected at 1m, 2m,3m and 6m. the data of vascular involvement, cranial MRI, vascular injury score and disease activity will also be collected at 6 months follow-up.

armGroups.label: RIC group
armGroups.description: The RIC protocol includes five cycles of 5-min inflation to 200mmHg and 5-min deflation.

armGroups.label: sham RIC group
armGroups.description: The sham RIC protocol includes five cycles of 5-min inflation to 60mmHg and 5-min deflation.

interventions.name: RIC
interventions.description: RIC is a non-invasive therapy that is performed by automated pneumatic cuffs placed on unilateral arms. The RIC protocol includes five cycles of 5-min inflation to 200mmHg and 5-min deflation.

interventions.name: sham-RIC
interventions.description: Sham-RIC is a non-invasive therapy that is performed by automated pneumatic cuffs placed on unilateral arms. The sham RIC protocol includes five cycles of 5-min inflation to 60mmHg and 5-min deflation.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Mean cerebral blood flow improvement rate
primaryOutcomes.description: Mean cerebral blood flow improvement rate ( mCBF-IR ) of TAK patients will be obtained by pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling ( pCASL ) -MRI.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: during baseline to 6 months after therapy

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Incidence of major adverse cerebrovascular events ( MACE )
secondaryOutcomes.description: MACEs are defined as the occurrence of stroke, transient ischemic attacks (TIAs), blindness in patients.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: during baseline to 6 months after therapy

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The change value of arterial transit time ( ATT )
secondaryOutcomes.description: The change value of arterial transit time ( ATT ) in pCASL hypoperfusion area compared with baseline
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: during baseline to 6 months after therapy

secondaryOutcomes.description: The change value of serum level of nerve growth factor (NGF) will be compared with baseline.

secondaryOutcomes.description: The change value of serum level of platelet activating factor (PAF) will be compared with baseline.

secondaryOutcomes.description: The change value of serum level of platelet growth factor ( PDGF ) will be compared with baseline.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The change value of Birmingham Vasculitis Activity Score (BVAS)
secondaryOutcomes.description: The investigator will record the score. The BVAS is the most effective validated tool to document disease activity, ranging from 0 to 63. A score greater than or equal to 15 indicates that the disease is active. The higher score means the higher disease activity and a worse outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The change value of the Indian Takayasu Clinical Activity Score (ITAS) 2010
secondaryOutcomes.description: The investigator will record the score. ITAS 2010, a useful measure of clinical disease activity, ranges from 0 to 51 points. A score greater than or equal to 2 indicates that the disease is active. The higher score means the higher disease activity and the worse outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The change value of the Vasculitis Damage Index (VDI)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Disease damage will be evaluated using the Vasculitis Damage Index (VDI). It ranges from 0 to 64 points. The higher score means the more severe vascular damage and the worse outcome.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: The change value of the number of affected blood vessels
secondaryOutcomes.description: The number of affected blood vessels will be performed by Doppler US, CT angiography, magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), or digital subtraction angiography. The change value of the number will be compared with baseline.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Rate of the usage of glucocorticoids
secondaryOutcomes.description: The investigator will observe and record the usage of glucocorticoids.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* All patients fulfilled the 1990 American College of Rheumatology Classification Criteria for TAK
* Inactive state
* Male and female, aged 18-65 years old
* The presence of supra-aortic vascular involvement ( including but not limited to the left and right sides of the common carotid artery, subclavian artery, vertebral artery involvement )
* Decreased cerebral blood perfusion in the whole brain ( compared with healthy people ) or local ( left and right brain contrast ) suggested by pseudo-Continuous arterial spin labeling ( pCASL ) -MRI
* Voluntary participation in this study, signed informed consent

Exclusion Criteria:

* Complications that endanger the function of important organs, such as uncontrollable heart failure, severe heart valve disease, severe hypertension, severe myocardial ischemia, pulmonary hypertension, acute cerebral infarction, arterial dissection or aneurysm rupture, etc
* There are serious complications, such as poorly controlled diabetes, renal insufficiency, cardiopulmonary insufficiency, mental illness or malignant tumor
* There were moderate to severe stenosis of brachial artery in both upper limbs
